section.para: The config command allows you to set up and manage configuration settings for Penify CLI. This document explains all available configuration options and how to use them.

section.title: Configuration Overview
section.para: Penify CLI stores configuration in a JSON file at ~/.penify/config.json. The configuration includes:

listitem.para: LLM (Large Language Model) settings for local commit message generation
JIRA integration settings for enhanced commit messages
API tokens and other credentials

literallayout.computeroutput:
# Configure LLM settings penify config llm
# Configure JIRA integration penify config jira

section.title: Web Interface
section.para: Running penify config llm opens a web interface in your browser where you can configure:

listitem.para: Model: The LLM model to use (e.g., gpt-3.5-turbo)
API Base URL: The endpoint URL for your LLM API (e.g., https://api.openai.com/v1)
API Key: Your authentication key for the LLM API

section.title: Supported LLMs
section.para: Penify CLI supports various LLM providers:

listitem.para: Model: gpt-3.5-turbo or gpt-4
API Base: https://api.openai.com/v1
API Key: Your OpenAI API key
Model: claude-instant-1 or claude-2
API Base: https://api.anthropic.com/v1
API Key: Your Anthropic API key
Model: llama2 or any model you have installed
API Base: http://localhost:11434
API Key: (leave blank)
Model: Your deployed model name
API Base: Your Azure endpoint
API Key: Your Azure API key

section.title: Web Interface
section.para: Running penify config jira opens a web interface where you can configure:

listitem.para: JIRA URL: Your JIRA instance URL (e.g., https://yourcompany.atlassian.net)
Username: Your JIRA username (typically your email)
API Token: Your JIRA API token
Log in to https://id.atlassian.com/manage-profile/security/api-tokens
Click "Create API token"
Give it a name (e.g., "Penify CLI")
Copy the generated token and paste it into the configuration

section.title: Configuration Locations
section.para: Penify CLI looks for configuration in multiple locations:

listitem.para: Project-specific: .penify/config.json in the Git repository root
User-specific: ~/.penify/config.json in your home directory

section.para: The project-specific configuration takes precedence if both exist.

section.title: Environment Variables
section.para: You can override configuration settings using environment variables:

listitem.para: PENIFY_API_TOKEN: Override the stored API token
PENIFY_LLM_MODEL: Override the configured LLM model
PENIFY_LLM_API_BASE: Override the configured LLM API base URL
PENIFY_LLM_API_KEY: Override the configured LLM API key
PENIFY_JIRA_URL: Override the configured JIRA URL
PENIFY_JIRA_USER: Override the configured JIRA username
PENIFY_JIRA_TOKEN: Override the configured JIRA API token

section.title: Command-Line Configuration
section.para: For advanced users or scripting, you can directly edit the configuration file:

literallayout.computeroutput:
# View current configuration cat ~/.penify/config.json
# Edit configuration with your preferred editor nano ~/.penify/config.json

section.title: Sharing Configuration
section.para: You can share configuration between machines by copying the .penify/config.json file. However, be cautious with API keys and credentials.

For team settings, consider:
Using a project-specific .penify/config.json with shared settings
Excluding API keys from shared configuration
Using environment variables for sensitive credentials

listitem.para:
**"Error reading configuration file"**
Check if the file exists: ls -la ~/.penify
Ensure it contains valid JSON: cat ~/.penify/config.json

**"Failed to connect to LLM API"**
Verify API base URL and API key
Check network connectivity to the API endpoint
Ensure your account has access to the specified model

**"Failed to connect to JIRA"**
Check JIRA URL format (should include https://)
Verify username and API token
Ensure your JIRA account has API access permissions
